faqs.answer: October 15–17, 2026 (Thu–Sat) at the KAFD Conference Center. Sessions start at 9:00 AM daily; Day 1 includes a 6:00–9:00 PM reception; Day 3 wraps by 3:00 PM. See the Schedule page for room-by-room times.
faqs.question: What are the dates and daily schedule?

faqs.answer: KAFD Conference Center, King Abdullah Financial District, Riyadh (Asia/Riyadh, UTC+3). Use the main conference entrance; security screening is required—please arrive 15–20 minutes early.
faqs.question: Where is the venue?

faqs.answer: Please submit the RSVP form on this site by September 20, 2026 so we can plan accreditation and logistics. Joy handles invitations and RSVP submissions; you’ll receive a confirmation email with next steps.
faqs.question: How do I register/RSVP?

faqs.answer: Badge pickup opens at 8:00 AM on Day 1 in the Plenary Foyer. Bring a government-issued photo ID; badges are required for entry. A help desk will assist with late arrivals and reprints during event hours.
faqs.question: When and where do I pick up my badge?

faqs.answer: Many nationalities are eligible for a Saudi eVisa or visa-on-arrival; others require a business/conference visa. Ensure your passport has 6+ months validity and health insurance. If you need an invitation letter or MOFA-coded support, note it in your RSVP and our team will assist. See the Transportation Guide for the official visa link.
faqs.question: Do I need a visa to attend?

faqs.answer: From King Khalid International Airport (RUH) it’s typically 25–45 minutes by car; allow up to 60 minutes at rush hours. Options: Riyadh Metro Line 4 from Airport T1–2 to KAFD Station (~35 minutes), ride‑hailing (Uber/Careem), or official taxi. Details and updates are on the Transportation Guide.
faqs.question: What are the best ways to get from RUH airport to KAFD?

faqs.answer: Yes. Peak-hour shuttles between select hotels and KAFD will operate; the timetable and pickup points will be posted on the Transportation page and emailed to registered guests closer to the event.
faqs.question: Will there be event shuttles from hotels?

faqs.answer: On-site/attached KAFD parking is available with security screening at entry. Allow extra time during morning peaks. To ease flows, we recommend ride‑hailing, the Metro, or event shuttles where possible.
faqs.question: Where should I park?

faqs.answer: The summit runs four tracks—Technical AI, Ethics & Safety, Business & Investment, and Government & Policy—with keynotes and panels in the Auditorium. Day 3 features hands‑on workshops and a closing keynote. See the Schedule for session times and rooms.
faqs.question: What is the program format?

faqs.answer: Business Smart, Riyadh‑appropriate: polished business wear with modest cuts; national dress is welcome. Headscarf is optional for international guests. Indoors are cool—bring a light layer.
faqs.question: What is the dress code?

faqs.answer: Yes—coffee breaks and lunch are provided each day, plus light bites at the Day 1 reception. All catering is halal and the event is alcohol‑free. Note dietary needs in your RSVP.
faqs.question: Are meals provided and is the event alcohol‑free?

faqs.answer: Yes. Prayer rooms are on site and clearly signposted. Friday includes an extended lunch/Jumu’ah buffer so you can attend prayers.
faqs.question: Are prayer rooms available and how is Friday handled?

faqs.answer: Yes. Main-stage sessions will offer live Arabic/English interpretation; details will appear on the Schedule and signage on site. Bilingual help desks are also available.
faqs.question: Will there be Arabic/English interpretation?

faqs.answer: Yes. Main sessions will be livestreamed with Arabic/English interpretation; the link will be posted on the Schedule. Selected sessions will be available on demand after the event.
faqs.question: Will sessions be livestreamed or recorded?

faqs.answer: Yes. Complimentary Wi‑Fi will be available throughout the conference center. The network name and password will be posted on-site and in the event app.
faqs.question: Is Wi‑Fi available at the venue?

faqs.answer: The venue has step‑free access, elevators, and accessible restrooms. Interpretation and reserved seating are available in the main hall. Share any mobility, sensory, or seating needs in your RSVP so we can assist.
faqs.question: What accessibility support is available?

faqs.answer: All attendees pass through security screening; bags may be checked. Please wear your badge at all times and carry a photo ID. Arrive 15–20 minutes early for screening, and follow staff instructions for any VIP motorcade holds.
faqs.question: What security measures should I expect?

faqs.answer: Riyadh in mid‑October is hot and very dry—daytime highs around 33–35°C with cooler evenings. Interiors are strongly air‑conditioned. Bring breathable fabrics, sunscreen/sunglasses, and a light layer.
faqs.question: What weather should I plan for?

faqs.answer: Stay near KAFD/Northern Ring for the shortest transfers, with overflow in Al Olaya and the Diplomatic Quarter. Room blocks and shuttle pickups will be posted on the Accommodations page—book early as late October can be busy.
faqs.question: Where should I stay?

faqs.answer: Use the Contact link on this site or visit the Help Desk at KAFD during event hours. Registered guests can also reply to their RSVP confirmation email for assistance.
faqs.question: Who can I contact for help?

faqs.answer: Yes. A staffed Speaker Lounge near the main stage will be available for prep, briefings, and light refreshments. Access is limited to guests tagged as Speakers; details will be emailed in your speaker briefing.
faqs.question: Is there a speaker lounge?

assumptions: Interpreted the host’s explicit window “October 15–17, 2026” as inclusive local dates at KAFD and set Asia/Riyadh as the IANA time zone.

Preserved the Thu–Sat pattern per the brief; in the GCC this overlaps the Fri–Sat weekend, supporting local/regional attendance while still accommodating global travel. Did not convert to a Tue–Thu pattern to avoid contradicting the host’s specified dates.

Segment times mirror the supplied schedule blocks: Day 1 sessions 09:00–18:00, reception 18:00–21:00; Day 2 sessions 09:00–18:00; Day 3 sessions 09:00–15:00. Times are recorded in UTC (Z) for precision and should be displayed in Asia/Riyadh (UTC+3, no DST).
Calendar conflict analysis (Jan 2026): High-severity competitor GITEX Global shifts to Dec 7–11, 2026 at Expo City Dubai (no overlap/±2-week conflict).

Calendar conflict analysis: Future Investment Initiative (FII) historically runs in late October in Riyadh (e.g., Oct 27–30, 2025). Official 2026 dates not posted yet; expect late-October timing. Our dates fall roughly 10–14 days before—medium severity due to VIP diaries and hotel compression, with potential positioning synergies.

Holiday considerations: U.S. Indigenous Peoples’/Columbus Day is Mon Oct 12, 2026 (medium–low impact on U.S. travel); Jewish Sukkot ends Oct 2 with Shemini Atzeret/Simchat Torah Oct 3–4 (outside ±1 week; low); China National Day Golden Week runs Oct 1–7 (ends >1 week before; low residual).
Strategic positioning: Occurs ~4 weeks after SDAIA’s Global AI Summit (Sep 15–17, 2026), reducing direct competition while enabling follow-on announcements/collaborations.
Operational note: Friday programming should include accommodation for Jumu’ah (midday prayers); assumed the host’s schedule will integrate this within the 09:00–18:00 block.

Research limitations: Some 2026 calendars remain tentative; used official releases and reputable press for 2026 (e.g., GITEX date shift, Global AI Summit) and prior-year patterns (e.g., FII 2025) to infer risk windows.

alternatives.rationale: Optimizes Tue–Thu pattern for international business travel (Mon arrival, Fri return) and weekday government availability. Sacrifices: proximity to U.S. Indigenous Peoples’/Columbus Day on Mon Oct 12 may slightly constrain U.S. travel; also trims the pre-weekend networking benefit of Thu–Sat. Confidence is high because it preserves October timing, avoids major regional tech events, and aligns with common conference cadence.

Optimizes Tue–Thu cadence and positions the event just ahead of Riyadh’s late-October mega-events, potentially boosting VIP/investor density and media. Sacrifices: increased risk of overlap with Future Investment Initiative (FII) patterns (late-October in Riyadh), which could strain hotel inventory and senior speaker schedules. Confidence is moderate due to these potential collisions.

Optimizes spacing from late-October investment events and keeps a clear runway after SDAIA’s Global AI Summit (mid-September). Sacrifices: proximity to China’s National Day Golden Week (Oct 1–7) and the Jewish holidays (Shemini Atzeret/Simchat Torah Oct 3–4) may dampen participation from some regions; also slightly hotter weather earlier in October. Confidence is lower given these tradeoffs.

decision.explanation:
KAFD Conference Center is selected as the primary venue to honor the host’s requirement to stage the summit within KAFD and to align the experience with Vision 2030’s future-forward narrative. It meets core functional needs (600-seat auditorium and four concurrent track rooms via multipurpose hall partitions), supports VIP/ministerial protocols with secured perimeter management, and provides strong branding moments across KAFD’s iconic architecture with metro adjacency for sustainable access. While the indicative rental is higher and airport transfers are slightly longer than peers, these trade-offs are justified by the strategic KAFD location, security posture, and district-level sustainability and digital credentials. RFECC is the leading contingency for maximum scalability (rooms/exhibit and parking) and fast RUH transfers. Hilton Riyadh offers a refined, budget-efficient hotel-conference alternative meeting the 4-track requirement with comfortable plenary headroom.

Availability diligence: Targeted searches as of 2026-01-11 found no conflicting public events at KAFD, RFECC, or Hilton on Oct 15–17, 2026. KAICC references (FII, UNIDO GC21) are maintained in evidence for context only.

venue.promptExcerpt: AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 — 500-person, four-track international AGI conference, Oct 15–17, 2026. Primary venue specified as King Abdullah Financial District Conference Center (KAFD). VIP speakers, ministerial keynotes, press, interpretation, and high-security flows.

budget.notes: Planning baseline for a 3‑day, four‑track, 500‑attendee summit at KAFD in Oct 2026 with ministerial/VIP presence, halal catering, broadcast‑grade AV, Arabic/English interpretation, hotel shuttles, and strong security. Estimates are inclusive of typical vendor fees and 15% KSA VAT where applicable; exchange planning uses the SAR peg at ~3.75 SAR per USD. Key benchmarks used: Riyadh day‑delegate catering commonly SAR 250–400 pp/day; large hall daily rentals often SAR 80k–150k; chauffeur S‑Class and 50‑seater coach rates aligned to Riyadh providers; interpreter booths/headsets and pro teams budgeted for main stage with expansion option. Assumes partnership offsets on venue hire due to strategic alignment with KAFD/partners. High range targets the full US$750k budget ceiling; low range reflects efficiencies and in‑kind support. Recommend locking venue/AV/catering early and maintaining the contingency at 10–12% through show week.

people.bio: Demis Hassabis is co‑founder and CEO of Google DeepMind, the research lab behind AlphaGo, AlphaZero, and AlphaFold. A former games prodigy and trained neuroscientist, he has led teams that published landmark work in deep reinforcement learning, planning, and AI for scientific discovery, with impact across Google and the wider research community. He advocates for safe, beneficial AI and cross‑disciplinary science. At AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 he delivers “Research Frontiers Toward AGI,” sharing progress on reasoning, memory, and long‑horizon planning.
people.title: Keynote Speaker

people.bio: Dario Amodei is the co‑founder and CEO of Anthropic, the AI research company behind the Claude family of models. A former VP of Research at OpenAI, he co‑authored influential work on large‑scale training, interpretability, and policy, including the 2016 paper “Concrete Problems in AI Safety.” His teams focus on constitutional AI, scalable oversight, and robust evaluation. At the Summit he speaks on “Scaling Compute for AGI,” exploring how the next order‑of‑magnitude in compute intersects with capability, access, and safety.
people.title: Plenary Speaker

people.bio: Dr. Fei‑Fei Li is the Sequoia Professor of Computer Science at Stanford University and co‑director of Stanford HAI. A pioneer of modern computer vision, she led the creation of ImageNet and has advanced human‑centered approaches to AI across healthcare, education, and society. Formerly Chief Scientist of AI/ML at Google Cloud, she co‑founded AI4ALL to broaden participation in AI. At AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 she delivers the keynote “Human‑Centered AGI,” focusing on dignity, agency, and trust in the design of intelligent systems.
people.title: Keynote Speaker

people.bio: Sam Altman is the co‑founder and CEO of OpenAI and a leading voice on the economics and governance of frontier AI. He previously served as president of Y Combinator, backing hundreds of startups, and has invested across energy, biotech, and AI. Under his leadership OpenAI introduced widely used systems such as ChatGPT and GPT‑4, catalyzing a wave of product innovation. He joins H.E. Fahd Al‑Rasheed for the Opening Fireside “The Future of Intelligence,” discussing AI’s trajectory and Riyadh’s role in the decade ahead.
people.title: Fireside Guest

people.bio: Mustafa Suleyman CBE is CEO of Microsoft AI and co‑founder of DeepMind, where he led applied AI before co‑founding Inflection AI. A long‑time advocate for responsible deployment, he helped forge partnerships between research and industry and co‑authored the bestselling book “The Coming Wave.” At AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 he delivers “Building AI Products & Agents,” outlining how breakthroughs in models, memory, and tool‑use are reshaping everyday products and the agentic operating systems of tomorrow.
people.title: Keynote Speaker

people.bio: Dr. Yann LeCun is Chief AI Scientist at Meta and a professor at NYU. A Turing Award laureate (with Geoffrey Hinton and Yoshua Bengio), he pioneered convolutional neural networks and modern deep learning. His research spans self‑supervised learning, energy‑based models, and open science. LeCun champions open innovation and pluralistic AI ecosystems. He will give the Closing Keynote “Open Innovation Paths to AGI,” exploring how openness, competition, and scientific rigor can accelerate safe, capable intelligence.
people.title: Closing Keynote Speaker

people.bio: Dr. Ilya Sutskever is a leading AI researcher known for foundational contributions to deep learning, including sequence‑to‑sequence learning and large‑scale neural network training. A co‑founder of OpenAI and its former Chief Scientist, he later founded Safe Superintelligence (SSI) to advance safety‑focused AI research. His work has shaped modern capability, alignment, and evaluation approaches. At AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 he leads “Alignment & Interpretability Advances,” a technical session on mechanistic understanding and safety mitigations.
people.title: Session Lead — Alignment & Interpretability

people.bio: H.E. Fahd Al‑Rasheed is an Advisor in the General Secretariat of the Council of Ministers of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia and Chairman of SCEGA. Formerly CEO of the Royal Commission for Riyadh City, he helped lead the capital’s transformation agenda and Riyadh’s successful bid for World Expo 2030. A champion of Vision 2030, he has held senior roles spanning investment, urban development, and global convenings. He hosts the Opening Fireside with Sam Altman and leads “Riyadh — Capital of the Future of Intelligence.”
people.title: Fireside Host & Keynote Panel Lead

people.bio: H.E. Dr. Abdullah bin Sharaf Alghamdi is President of the Saudi Data & AI Authority (SDAIA), at the rank of minister. He led the establishment of SDAIA and the National Strategy for Data & AI and previously directed the National Information Center. A professor and technologist, he has advanced national data platforms, AI governance, and digital transformation across sectors. At the Summit he leads the keynote panel “National AI Strategy & Vision 2030.”
people.title: Keynote Panel Lead — President, SDAIA

people.bio: H.E. Eng. Abdullah Al‑Swaha is Saudi Arabia’s Minister of Communications and Information Technology, steering the Kingdom’s digital economy, connectivity, and talent agenda. Under his leadership, KSA has accelerated cloud, AI, cybersecurity, and entrepreneurship initiatives and convened global platforms such as LEAP. He leads the keynote panel “Digital Economy & Innovation,” bringing together leaders on infrastructure, skilling, and entrepreneurship to enable an AI‑powered economy.
people.title: Keynote Panel Lead — Minister of Communications & IT (MCIT)

people.bio: H.E. Khalid A. Al‑Falih is Saudi Arabia’s Minister of Investment, leading national strategy to attract and enable global capital and partnerships across sectors including technology. A seasoned executive and former energy minister and Aramco chairman, he has overseen large‑scale industrial, infrastructure, and policy programs central to Vision 2030. At the Summit he leads the keynote panel “Investment, Policy & Global Partnerships,” connecting founders, investors, and policymakers.
people.title: Keynote Panel Lead — Minister of Investment (MISA)

people.bio: Dr. Aisha Al‑Rashid is an AI ethics and safety researcher focused on evaluation governance, red‑teaming practices, and incident reporting frameworks in high‑stakes deployments. She contributes to regional working groups and advises on practical standards for responsible AI adoption in the public and private sectors. At AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 she leads “Safety Standards & Evaluations for AGI,” a session on robust evals, governance‑by‑design, and pragmatic risk management.
people.title: Session Lead — Safety Standards & Evaluations

people.bio: Jensen Huang is the founder, president, and CEO of NVIDIA, the company that pioneered GPU‑accelerated computing and platforms that power modern AI. A visionary builder and longtime champion of accelerated computing, he has guided NVIDIA’s ecosystem of developers, researchers, and enterprises worldwide. He is invited to join the Opening Fireside conversation; confirmation TBC.
people.title: Invited Speaker (TBC)

areaCandidates.label: King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD)
areaCandidates.watchOuts: Peak-hour traffic on Northern Ring/King Fahd Rd; heightened security protocols and vehicle screening windows; coordinate prayer room access and Friday timings.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: Event home base per brief; ultramodern district with iconic architecture, secure perimeters, and direct access to executive offices. Walkable skywalks and nearby 4–5★ hotels enable seamless VIP flows and late-session networking.

areaCandidates.label: Al Olaya / Kingdom Centre Corridor
areaCandidates.watchOuts: Congestion on Olaya St. and King Fahd Rd during rush hours; plan buffered shuttle timetables.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: Riyadh’s central business and retail spine; dense cluster of premium hotels, dining, and corporate HQs. Ideal for executive lodging, investor meetings, and press interviews within a short drive of KAFD.

areaCandidates.label: Diplomatic Quarter (Al Safarat)

links.title: Royal Commission for Riyadh City – Diplomatic Quarter Program

areaCandidates.watchOuts: Perimeter controls and embassy security rules can limit access points and load-in windows; advance permitting is essential.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: Embassy enclave with landscaped plazas and controlled access—appropriate for ministerial roundtables, bilateral meetings, and small VIP receptions.

areaCandidates.label: Diriyah (At‑Turaif / Bujairi Terrace)
areaCandidates.watchOuts: Occasional road closures and ticketed access for seasonal activations; heritage‑site restrictions on staging, amplified sound, and branding.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: World‑heritage setting and flagship giga‑project that aligns with Vision 2030 storytelling—strong backdrop for cultural dinners or leadership dialogues.

areaCandidates.label: Hittin / Boulevard Riyadh City
areaCandidates.watchOuts: Seasonality—some activations are event‑driven; confirm hours, sound limits, and crowd control plans.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: Entertainment and dining hub near KAFD suitable for informal meetups and private buy‑outs during Riyadh Season; supports evening networking.

areaCandidates.label: Qurtubah (Airport Corridor)
areaCandidates.watchOuts: Fewer flagship 5★ properties; commuter traffic spikes around office hours on Airport Rd.
areaCandidates.whyItFits: Strategic for late‑night arrivals and early‑morning departures; growing stock of business hotels and serviced apartments along Northern Ring Road and Airport Rd.

locationInsights.lodging: Primary clusters for room blocks: (1) KAFD/Northern Ring (walkable or <10 min to sessions), (2) Al Olaya/King Fahd Rd (business hotels with strong dining), and (3) Diplomatic Quarter/West Riyadh (quieter, secure enclave). Late‑October investment events can compress inventory—lock blocks early and use overflow in Hittin/Diriyah corridors.
locationInsights.transit: RUH → KAFD ~30–35 km. Typical transfers: 25–35 minutes off-peak; 40–60 minutes in rush hour. Ride‑hailing and executive car services are widely used. The Riyadh Metro has been rolling out in phases; KAFD Station links the district to the wider network—confirm operating status and frequencies before relying on rail for delegates.
locationInsights.visaOrEntry: Many nationalities are eligible for Saudi eVisa/visa-on-arrival; others require an embassy-issued business/conference visa. For non-eligible passports, arrange MOFA-coded invitations via the host entity well in advance. Passports should have 6+ months validity; health insurance is typically mandatory. Build 3–6 weeks’ lead time for attendees needing consular processing.
locationInsights.climateWindow: Best months for comfort: late Oct–Apr. October in Riyadh is warm-to-hot and very dry: typical highs ~35°C and lows ~21°C with minimal rainfall (~1 mm). Plan indoor midday sessions and outdoor evening functions; ensure ample hydration and shaded transfers.
locationInsights.safetyAndCulture: Riyadh maintains a high security posture for VIP events. Coordinate motorcade routes and screening zones with district security. Respect prayer times, especially Friday Jumu’ah; provide prayer rooms and schedule buffers. The Kingdom is alcohol‑free; ensure halal catering and culturally appropriate branding and dress codes.

avoidAreas: Far-south/southeast industrial districts (e.g., Second Industrial City)
Sites requiring >45 minutes from RUH at peak traffic
Compounds with restricted external guest access
venueSearchBrief.logisticsNotes: Design shuttle loops RUH↔KAFD with peak buffers (08:00–10:00, 16:00–19:00). Use Northern Ring/King Fahd Rd corridors with contingency routes. Stagger VIP arrivals, assign dedicated screening lanes, and pre-clear license plates. Schedule Friday sessions around Jumu’ah (midday).

Capacity for 500 attendees with four concurrent track rooms + plenary
Dedicated VIP green rooms and secure motorcade access

Broadcast-grade AV with simultaneous interpretation and press/workflow spaces
softPreferences: Iconic, future-forward architecture aligned to Vision 2030
Walkable access to dining and 4–5★ hotels
Proximity to Riyadh Metro KAFD Station (if operational)
Expansive foyers for exhibits and partner activations
Robust digital signage/LED surfaces for wayfinding and branding
venueSearchBrief.lodgingClusterNotes: Prioritize room blocks within KAFD/Northern Ring (0–4 km), with overflow in Al Olaya and Diplomatic Quarter (≈9–12 km). Ensure VIP suites and secure drop-offs; maintain late check-ins for transcontinental arrivals.

overview.name: AGI Summit Riyadh 2026
summary: Join global founders, researchers, investors, and policymakers in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia on October 15–17, 2026 at the King Abdullah Financial District Conference Center (KAFD). The summit runs four tracks—Technical AI, Ethics & Safety, Business & Investment, and Government & Policy—for approximately 500 attendees. Cadence: Day 1 Opening + Technical (09:00–18:00) and reception (18:00–21:00); Day 2 Ethics/Policy + Business (09:00–18:00); Day 3 Workshops + Closing Keynote (09:00–15:00).

Highlights include an opening fireside with H.E. Fahd Al‑Rasheed and Sam Altman (Jensen Huang invited), ministerial keynote panels led by SDAIA, MCIT, and MISA, and headliners such as Dr. Demis Hassabis, Dr. Fei‑Fei Li, Mustafa Suleyman, and Dr. Yann LeCun, plus technical sessions with Dr. Ilya Sutskever and Dr. Aisha Al‑Rashid. Arabic/English interpretation, on‑site prayer rooms, and halal catering are provided.

Explore /schedule, /speakers, /dress-code, and /travel, then RSVP at /rsvp by September 20, 2026. Venue: KAFD, Asia/Riyadh (UTC+3). The aim is to elevate Riyadh as the capital of the future of intelligence and showcase Vision 2030 as a platform for innovation.

overview.summary: Three days of keynotes, four tracks, hands-on workshops, and ministerial dialogues at KAFD—advancing the future of intelligence in alignment with Vision 2030.

overview.description: A bold, globally inclusive three-day conference on the future of AGI, held October 15–17, 2026 at the King Abdullah Financial District Conference Center (KAFD) in Riyadh. Organized by SCEGA with SDAIA, MCIT, and MISA, the summit convenes 500 founders, researchers, investors, and policymakers across four tracks to position Riyadh as the place where the future of intelligence is defined—in alignment with Vision 2030.

schedule.scheduleName: AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 — The Future of AGI
schedule.notesForPlanners: Primary venue: KAFD Conference Center. Run all global sessions on the Main track and pause breakouts accordingly (alignsWithMain=true on all secondary tracks). Friday programming includes a 90‑minute lunch + Jumu’ah buffer; ensure clearly signed prayer rooms near foyer. Livestream all Main sessions with Arabic/English interpretation (links TBA; plan 10‑min pre‑roll). VIP flows: separate green rooms, secured drops, staggered arrivals. All catering halal; alcohol‑free. Use Technical Track rooms A–C in the multipurpose hall for concurrent breakouts; Auditorium for Main. Keep 10–15 minute buffer between room turns. Media zones and press briefings scheduled during breaks/lunch. Sustainability: encourage Metro/KAFD walking where feasible; minimize printed materials.

risks.risk: Hotel compression due to late‑October mega‑events in Riyadh (e.g., FII patterns).
risks.mitigation: Contract primary/overflow blocks by early February; publish lodging early on Joy; maintain 10–15% overflow inventory and shuttle from secondary clusters.

risks.risk: Ministerial/VIP diary conflicts reduce availability for key sessions.
risks.mitigation: Engage protocol now with multiple time windows per VIP; schedule rehearsals and motorcade buffers; maintain backup moderators and panel compositions.

risks.risk: Simultaneous interpretation and streaming complexity causes technical failures.
risks.mitigation: Award vendors in March; run full-system tests by Oct 1; provision 1 Gbps dedicated (option 10 Gbps); add redundant encoders/networks and onsite translation tech support.

risks.risk: Friday Jumu’ah overlap causes crowding and timing stress.
risks.mitigation: Keep extended Friday lunch/prayer buffer; signpost prayer rooms; brief speakers to end on time before midday.

risks.risk: Visa/MOFA processing delays for non‑eligible passports and media.
risks.mitigation: Publish visa guidance in June; issue MOFA letters by July 20; track high‑risk cases; coordinate with partners for escalations.

risks.risk: Security/motorcade holds disrupt attendee flows and schedule timing.
risks.mitigation: Finalize security plan v2 in May; perform tabletop (Oct 6) and rehearsal (Oct 14); pre‑communicate door holds on signage and in app.

risks.risk: Dust/weather event impacts outdoor reception or arrivals.
risks.mitigation: Confirm indoor fallback (Oct 8); deploy door brushes/filters; prep comms templates to move networking indoors if AQI/visibility dips.

risks.risk: Metro operational uncertainty affects transport messaging.
risks.mitigation: Plan shuttles regardless; position Metro as optional and confirm status D‑30; push final transport guidance in Know‑Before‑You‑Go (Oct 7).

risks.risk: Production scope creep strains the US$750k budget.
risks.mitigation: Lock stage/scenic by Apr 30; track change orders weekly; hold 10–15% contingency; offset with sponsorship closes (50% by Apr 15, 70% by Jun 15).

timeline.title: AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 — Planning Timeline

timeline.summary: Nine months out from AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 (Oct 15–17 at KAFD), this timeline prioritizes locking the venue and room blocks, aligning ministerial/VIP schedules, launching the website and RSVP, awarding AV/interpretation/streaming vendors, and building the program grid across four tracks. It then sequences production design, security/transport, marketing and registration acceleration, and show-readiness gates—with clear owners, dependencies, and Joy-powered actions for website, RSVP, schedule, accommodations, guest list, and attendee messaging.

timeframe.pacing: 9.1 months remaining — on track if KAFD hold, VIP/protocol alignment, and website/RSVP launch are completed by early February; maintain monthly vendor awards and sponsorship gates to avoid compression.

dataQuality.notes: Aligned with Riyadh business norms, indoor AC conditions, and the event’s businessCasual snapshot; adds clear guidance for ministerial keynotes and cultural sensitivity.

dressCode.name: Business Smart (Riyadh-appropriate)
dressCode.hostNotes: Keep guest-facing tone as Business Smart to align with the event snapshot’s businessCasual formality while respecting ministerial/VIP presence. Speaker ops: brief all main-stage speakers and government participants to dress Business Formal (suit/tie or national formal), especially for opening, ministerial keynotes, and press photos. Print a short cultural note: “Modest, Riyadh-appropriate business attire; national dress welcome.” Avoid on-site enforcement friction—provide guidance in pre-arrival emails and the website FAQ. Place a small supply of emergency layers (neutral shawls/blazers), lint rollers, and shoe-shine near green rooms. Confirm that abaya/headscarf are not required at KAFD and that prayer room access is signed. Reception style mirrors daytime (no costume change).
dressCode.description: Polished business wear for a high-level, international conference. Think blazers, dresses, or suits; ties are optional. Choose modest cuts (covered shoulders; hemlines at or below the knee; no sheer/low-cut pieces). National and cultural dress is warmly welcomed (e.g., thobe/bisht, abaya; headscarf optional for international guests). Speakers and photo moments: consider elevating to business formal (suit and tie or equivalent). Evening reception follows the same Business Smart tone—no outfit change required, but you may add a jacket or statement accessory. Indoors are cool with strong AC; outdoors can feel hot and very dry in October, so breathable fabrics and light layers work best.
dressCode.culturalContext: Riyadh/GCC business etiquette: modest, professional attire; national dress is common and welcome. Abaya is not required for international visitors at conference venues; head coverings are a personal choice except at religious sites (not part of this program).

audienceGuidelines.men: Business Smart: suit or blazer with dress shirt or smart knit; tie optional. Trousers or chino-style pants; polished dress shoes or sleek loafers. For main-stage speaking or official photos, opt for a full suit with tie. National dress (thobe, with optional bisht for formal moments) is welcome. Avoid shorts, distressed denim, athletic sneakers, and loud graphics.
audienceGuidelines.women: Business Smart with modest cuts: dresses or skirts at or below the knee, tailored trousers with blouse, or a pantsuit. Covered shoulders; avoid sheer or low-cut pieces. Closed-toe flats or heels recommended. A lightweight layer (blazer, shawl, or abaya if you prefer) helps with strong indoor AC. Headscarf is optional for international guests. For main-stage or official photos, elevate to a tailored suit or formal sheath/midi dress with jacket. National dress and abaya are welcome.
audienceGuidelines.unisex: General tips: choose breathable fabrics (it’s hot and very dry outside; interiors are cool). Keep silhouettes professional and modest. National/cultural attire from all countries is encouraged. For the evening reception, maintain the same Business Smart look—add a jacket, abaya, or understated accessory if you wish. Please avoid shorts, athleisure, casual tees, distressed denim, beachwear, or overly flashy logos.

dressCode.internalRecommendations: Default to Business Smart for all three days. Add a line in speaker confirmations: “Stage dress: Business Formal or national formal.” Include a short FAQ item clarifying modest norms, footwear, and headscarf optionality for international guests. Pre-brief photography teams to be culturally sensitive. Remind production to manage stage temperature (strong AC) and provide anti-slip stage surfaces to accommodate traditional footwear. Include a discrete note for international VIPs: a bisht/abaya is not required but may be worn for ceremonial photos at their discretion.

heroImage.eventDescription: AGI Summit Riyadh 2026 — The Future of AGI is a three-day international multi-track conference taking place October 15–17, 2026 at the King Abdullah Financial District Conference Center (KAFD) in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. Organized by SCEGA in partnership with SDAIA, the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (MCIT), and the Ministry of Investment (MISA). The program runs four tracks: Technical AI; Ethics & Safety; Business & Investment; Government & Policy. Schedule: Day 1 (Thu Oct 15) Opening Plenary + Technical Track 09:00–18:00, Evening Reception 18:00–21:00; Day 2 (Fri Oct 16) Ethics & Safety + Government & Policy; Business & Investment 09:00–18:00; Day 3 (Sat Oct 17) Workshops + Closing Keynote 09:00–15:00. Attendance: approximately 500 global founders, researchers, investors, and policymakers. Confirmed speakers include Dr. Demis Hassabis, Dario Amodei, Dr. Fei-Fei Li, Sam Altman, Dr. Aisha Al‑Rashid, Mustafa Suleyman, Dr. Yann LeCun, and Dr. Ilya Sutskever. Keynote/panel requirements include an opening fireside featuring H.E. Fahd Al‑Rasheed with Sam Altman (aspirational inclusion of Jensen Huang) and four ministerial keynote panels featuring leadership from SDAIA, MCIT, and MISA. Objective: convene global leaders to position Riyadh as a hub for the future of intelligence in alignment with Saudi Arabia’s Vision 2030.

legs.label: Ethics & Safety + Government & Policy; Business & Investment (Sessions)

items.name: Kingdom Centre Sky Bridge
items.description: Ride to the 99th‑floor Sky Bridge for sweeping views of Riyadh—spectacular by day or after dark, and just a short drive from KAFD. Timed tickets are recommended.

items.name: KAFD Skywalks & Public Art
items.description: Explore KAFD’s record‑setting elevated skywalk network threaded between striking towers—an easy, shaded stroll for fresh air between sessions or at sunset.

items.name: Boulevard Riyadh City
items.description: Riyadh’s high‑energy entertainment zone with giant LED screens, cafés, theaters, and promenade vibes. Expect peak crowds on weekend nights.

items.name: Bujairi Terrace (Diriyah)
items.description: Open‑air dining terraces overlooking the UNESCO‑listed At‑Turaif district—Najdi flavors and top global restaurants about 20 minutes from KAFD.

items.name: The Globe at Al Faisaliah
items.description: Fine dining inside the iconic golden geodesic sphere atop Al Faisaliah Tower with panoramic city views. Smart‑casual dress; valet available.

items.name: Roshn Front
items.description: Open‑air lifestyle complex with restaurants, boutiques, and illuminated fountains—easygoing evening meetups and walks.

items.name: Wadi Namar Park
items.description: Palm‑lined lake and 2‑km corniche beneath Namar Dam—a calm, scenic spot for an after‑hours stroll under the palms.

items.name: Tahlia Street (Prince Mohammed bin Abdulaziz St.)

location.line1: Tahlia Street (Prince Mohammed bin Abdulaziz St.)

items.description: Riyadh’s classic dining boulevard—lively after 8 pm—with upscale cafés, restaurants, and people‑watching along the palm‑lined strip.

groups.label: Riyadh — Day 1 evening: after the reception

tours.title: Riyadh Full‑Day: Museum, Masmak & City Highlights

items.description: The Kingdom’s flagship museum charts Arabia’s story from prehistory to unification. Modern galleries, English signage, and a pleasant gardened campus. Plan 60–90 minutes.

items.name: Al Masmak Fortress Museum

items.description: A 19th‑century mud‑brick fort central to Riyadh’s founding—restored rooms, artifacts, and the iconic gateway near Qasr Al‑Hukm.

items.name: Murabba Historical Palace

tours.title: Riyadh City Heritage Tour (Masmak, Murabba, Souq)

items.description: Early 20th‑century palace of King Abdulaziz within the King Abdulaziz Historical Center—classic Najdi architecture and period exhibits.

items.name: Souq Al Zal (Traditional Market)

tours.title: Riyadh City Heritage Tour (Masmak, Murabba, Souq)

items.description: Riyadh’s oldest souq—antiques, carpets, incense, coffee tools, and crafts. A short walk from Masmak; cash and cards widely accepted.

items.name: JAX District (Diriyah)
items.description: Converted warehouses turned creative hub—galleries, studios, residencies, and pop‑ups showcasing contemporary Saudi art and design.

items.description: UNESCO‑listed birthplace of the Saudi state. Walk atmospheric alleys, Salwa Palace, and curated galleries—pair with dining at nearby Bujairi Terrace.

items.description: Epic Tuwaiq escarpment with vast desert vistas—popular at sunset. Allow 6–7 hours round‑trip with 4x4 transport and water; weather‑dependent.

items.description: Classic Riyadh desert playground for dune bashing, quad biking, camel rides, and sunset photos—best visited with a licensed operator and transfers.

dataQuality.notes: Climatology-based outlook for Oct 15–17, 2026 in Riyadh using historical norms and sunrise/sunset tables; specific daily forecasts will be refined inside D-7.

daily.summary: Hot, very dry, and sunny through the day with a light NW breeze. Indoors are well air‑conditioned; hydrate between sessions and limit midday sun.
advisories: Heat/UV: Strong sun 10:30–15:30—use sunscreen and sunglasses.
Hydration: Very low humidity; drink water regularly.
Air: Low probability of blowing dust; monitor local NCM advisories if winds increase.

itinerary.label: Opening + Technical Track (Sessions)
itinerary.guestHighlights:
Expect a warm-to-hot desert day with clear skies; brief outdoor walks feel hot, while interiors are cool.
Sunglasses, sunscreen, and a refillable water bottle are smart to have.

daily.summary: Warm, dry evening after a hot day—around 28–30°C at 19:00 with a gentle NW breeze. Skies clear; rain unlikely.
advisories: Comfort: Outdoor networking feels warm; minimal sweat due to low humidity.
Air: Dust risk low; visibility generally 10 km.
Note: Indoor spaces can feel cool due to AC—light layer may be comfortable.

itinerary.label: Evening Reception
itinerary.guestHighlights:
Pleasant, warm evening outdoors with clear skies and a light breeze.
It’s very dry—hydrate, and consider a light layer for cool indoor AC.

daily.summary: Sunny, hot, and very dry with a light NW breeze. Little to no rain expected; strongest sun near midday.
advisories: Heat/UV: High UV midday—sunscreen, hat, and sunglasses recommended.
Hydration: Provide easy water access; low humidity accelerates dehydration.
Air: Low likelihood of dust; monitor if winds freshen.

itinerary.label: Ethics & Safety + Government & Policy; Business & Investment (Sessions)
itinerary.guestHighlights:
Another bright, hot day with very dry air—shade and water help between sessions.
Interiors stay cool—carry a light layer if you chill easily.

daily.summary: Still sunny and very dry, trending a touch less hot. Light NW winds; rain chances remain very low.
advisories: UV: Strong late morning sun—sunscreen and sunglasses advised.
Comfort: Morning feels more comfortable; afternoons still hot.
Air: Dust unlikely but possible; check same‑day forecast.

itinerary.label: Workshops + Closing Keynote
itinerary.guestHighlights:
Slightly less hot but still bright and dry—mornings feel comfortable for transfers.
Sunscreen and sunglasses remain useful; light layers help indoors.

weatherReport.guestHighlights:
Expect warm-to-hot, very dry weather—daytime highs around 33–35°C with clear skies, easing to 21–26°C at night.
The sun is strong and rain is unlikely; sunglasses, sunscreen, and a refillable water bottle go a long way.
Indoor venues are well air‑conditioned—light, breathable layers keep you comfortable.
weatherReport.hostPlanningNotes: Overall rain risk is very low. Provide shade at outdoor queues/transfers and run abundant hydration points. Strong AC indoors—offer light blankets or advise layers to avoid thermal shock. UV peaks 11:00–15:00; consider sunscreen stations near entries. Friday (Oct 16) programming should include a Jumu’ah buffer around midday. Low probability of dust events in October; maintain a contingency (door brushes, additional filtration at entries, comms to move outdoor meetups inside if visibility drops). For the evening reception, outdoor conditions are favorable; optional fans are adequate—misters generally unnecessary in very dry air.
weatherReport.internalRiskAssessment: Forecast horizon: long‑range climate guidance only—values are climatological estimates for mid‑October in Riyadh. Disruption risk is low from rain, moderate from heat/UV (midday), and low from dust (autumn frequency is minimal, but events can occur). Mitigations: hydration/shade; sunscreen distribution; monitor Saudi NCM and WMO SDS‑WAS advisories 72–24 hours out; prepare an indoor fallback for the reception if an atypical dust event materializes; share AC comfort note with guests to bring light layers.

accommodations.note: Booking guidance: To stay close to the venue (KAFD), target the Northern Ring/Al Olaya cluster. Off‑peak transfers are typically 5–20 minutes; allow up to 30–45 minutes at rush hours. Riyadh hotels compress in late October around major events—book by mid‑August 2026 for best rates. Alcohol is not served in the Kingdom; all catering is halal. Many nationalities are eligible for an eVisa; if you require an invitation letter for consular processing, contact the organizers early. Shuttle pick‑ups will be scheduled from selected properties; final hotel block details will be posted here once confirmed.

links.title: Saudi Arabia visa and entry regulations

travelItems.name: King Khalid International Airport
travelItems.notes: RUH is a 24/7 hub with multiple terminals; follow signage for Metro (T1–T2), taxi, rideshare, and car rentals.

transferOptions.notes: Riyadh Metro Line 4 (Yellow) runs Airport Terminals 1–2 ⇄ KAFD. Trains every ~5–7 minutes; operating roughly 06:00–00:00. Buy tickets in the Darb app or at station machines; tap-to-pay cards accepted.
Official metered taxis are available at RUH ranks and via the Taxi – Ajra app. Off-peak 25–35 min; allow 40–60 min in rush hours. Cards widely accepted; ask for a receipt.
Uber and Careem operate citywide with designated airport pickup zones at each terminal. For drop-off, set “KAFD Conference Center.”

internationalTips: Many nationalities are eligible for Saudi eVisa; others require a business/conference visa—check requirements and allow 3–6 weeks if consular processing is needed.
Passports must have 6+ months validity; travel medical insurance is typically required.
Carry your hotel/venue address for immigration forms and ground transport.
Saudi Arabia observes Friday Jumu’ah (midday prayer). Expect heavier traffic around noon on Fridays.

travelItems.name: Riyadh Metro (Airport ⇄ KAFD)

links.title: How to use the Riyadh Metro

travelItems.notes: Line 4 (Yellow) connects Airport Terminals 1–2 to KAFD in about 35 minutes. Trains every ~5–7 minutes; operating roughly 06:00–00:00. Standard 2-hour ticket SAR 4; First Class SAR 10. Interchange at KAFD for Lines 1 (Blue) and 6 (Purple). Stations are accessible; women-only sections available.

travelItems.name: Uber
travelItems.notes: Reliable option across Riyadh and at RUH. Use the terminal-designated pickup zones. Expect surge pricing at peaks; consider scheduling rides in advance.

travelItems.name: Careem
travelItems.notes: Careem operates throughout Riyadh with easy airport pickups. You can prebook, choose car types, and pay by card or Apple/Google Pay.

travelItems.name: Taxi – Ajra (Official Saudi Taxi)
travelItems.notes: Government-backed e-hailing for licensed taxis. Metered fares; cards commonly accepted. At RUH, follow taxi signs to the rank or book through the app.

travelItems.name: Hertz Saudi Arabia
travelItems.notes: International Driving Permit recommended alongside your home-country license; credit card required for deposit. Driving is on the right with extensive speed cameras. Parking available in KAFD garages; allow extra time for security screening at venue perimeters.

arrivalAdvice.guestSummary: Plan to arrive by the evening of Wed Oct 14, 2026. Sessions run Thu–Sat (Oct 15–17) starting at 9:00 AM daily; consider departing after 6:00 PM on Sat Oct 17 or on Sun Oct 18 for the smoothest journey.

transportationGuide.guestOverview: Fly into RUH (King Khalid International Airport). It’s about 30–45 minutes to KAFD by car depending on traffic, or roughly 35 minutes by the Riyadh Metro (Line 4/Yellow) direct from Airport Terminals 1–2 to KAFD Station. Arrive the day before Day 1 to be fresh for the 9:00 AM start.
